questions.question_text:
The following table exists in the production database:

//IMG//


A regulatory requirement states that the company must mask the username for events that are older than six months based on the current date when the data is queried.

How can the requirement be met without duplicating the event data and making sure it is applied when creating views using the table or cloning the table?

choices.B: Use a row level policy on the user_events table using an entitlement table with valid dates.
choices.D: Use a secure view on the user_events table using a case statement on the username column.
choices.A: Use a masking policy on the username column using an entitlement table with valid dates.
choices.C: Use a masking policy on the username column with event_timestamp as a conditional column.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct, as ukpino explained in his second comment.

Selected Answer: A
C does not seem right, because event_timestamp does not matter, current date being queried does. A seems more accurate.

comments.content: Actually changing to C, event-timestamp would be the column to be compared against the current datetime, C makes sense

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDF
BDF. The others are not data modelling methods..

B: Dimensional Modeling (Kimball): This approach organizes data into fact and dimension tables. It's widely used in data warehousing to optimize for query performance and ease of understanding for end-users. Snowflake supports this model well due to its columnar storage and performance optimization features.
D: Inmon/3NF: This model, proposed by Bill Inmon, focuses on a normalized structure (Third Normal Form) which is more flexible and reduces redundancy. Snowflake’s capabilities support the normalized model, ensuring data integrity and reducing storage costs.
F: Data Vault: This modeling approach is designed to provide long-term historical storage of data from multiple operational systems. It supports agile and scalable data integration and changes. Snowflake’s support for semi-structured data and its efficient storage makes it a good fit for the Data Vault methodology.

questions.question_text: Which data models can be used when modeling tables in a Snowflake environment? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. You can't replicate external tables.

Selected Answer: C
C. Replicate the database ensuring the replicated database is in the same region as the external tables.

This ensures that the external tables remain accessible and performant since they are in the same region as the primary database.
I think it's B, one has to move the external table before replication because otherwise the replication process could rise an error

choices.A: Create a clone of the primary database then replicate the database.
choices.C: Replicate the database ensuring the replicated database is in the same region as the external tables.
choices.B: Move the external tables to a database that is not replicated, then replicate the primary database.
choices.D: Share the primary database with an account in the same region that the database will be replicated to.

questions.question_text:
A Snowflake Architect is setting up database replication to support a disaster recovery plan. The primary database has external tables.

How should the database be replicated?

discussion.content:
BCE are correct due to the following reasons:
For persisted query results of all sizes, the cache expires after 24 hours.
Each time the persisted result for a query is reused, Snowflake resets the 24-hour retention period for the result, up to a maximum of 31 days from the date and time that the query was first executed. After 31 days, the result is purged and the next time the query is submitted, a new result is generated and persisted.
How is F not a correct answer? It is more correct than B, since a result cache be kicked out of memory before 24 hours if there are newer results coming in.

comments.content: Result set cache can be used between different virtual warehouses

discussion.content: F, E, C, B, A is valid. I have a doubt with A, but the rest is fine. Are these questions well posed? Or does it refer only to the features that are explicitly in the documentation? B, C, E 100%, since it is in the documentation explicitly, but F AND B are fine implicitly.
Answer is B,C,E and is validated

Selected Answer: BCE
Chosen answer BCE is correct

questions.question_text: What are some of the characteristics of result set caches? (Choose three.)

choices.C: Each time persisted results for a query are used, a 24-hour retention period is reset.
choices.E: The retention period can be reset for a maximum of 31 days.
choices.F: The result set cache is not shared between warehouses.
choices.D: The data stored in the result cache will contribute to storage costs.
choices.A: Time Travel queries can be executed against the result set cache.
choices.B: Snowflake persists the data results for 24 hours.

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: C 
Snowflake SQL REST API can be used to develop applications and integrations that can READ and WRITE data to Snowflake without installing any additional software on the application server.

C: Snowflake SQL REST API: This option allows you to execute SQL statements on Snowflake using RESTful HTTP requests. It does not require any additional software to be installed on the application server. You can use standard HTTP methods to interact with Snowflake, making it an ideal choice for applications that need to read and write data to Snowflake without additional installations.

questions.question_text:
An Architect is integrating an application that needs to read and write data to Snowflake without installing any additional software on the application server.

How can this requirement be met?

choices.C: Use the Snowflake SQL REST API.
